etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in Robert Dallington (b. 1561), author and courtier. From Italian quattrino quatrin

definitions: A small coin of low value used in a number of Italian states from the 14th century until (in the Papal States) the 19th century (originally a billon coin worth four denari, but by the 16th century usually a copper piece and often the least valuable coin in production). Hence also: (the type of) any coin of low value.
